title: Hebrew (1817) Hebrew New Testament (Alexander)
description:
The 1817 Hebrew New Testament, translated by Alexander and published by the London Society for Promoting Christianity amongst the Jews, represents a pivotal moment in biblical translation history. Printed by A. Macintosh in Spitalfields, London, this work aimed to make Christian scriptures accessible to Jewish audiences in their native language. The initiative was part of a broader 19th-century movement by missionary organizations to spread Christianity within Jewish communities.

The London Society for Promoting Christianity amongst the Jews, also known as the London Jews' Society, spearheaded these efforts, including translating Christian texts into Hebrew and establishing educational institutions for outreach. This edition holds linguistic and cultural significance, as it sought to present the Christian message within a familiar framework to Jewish people, thus exemplifying the complex interplay of language, religion, and cultural engagement in missionary activities during this period.
